title: Poor performance of std::iter::range (vs while-loop) on < 64-bit ints

labels.name: I-slow
labels.description: Problems and improvements with respect to performance of generated code.

body:
I've found that `std::iter::range` performs very poorly with ints of size less than 64-bits when compared to a while-loop:

```
test i16::range_ ... bench: 1337 ns/iter (+/- 37)
test i16::while_ ... bench: 651 ns/iter (+/- 17)

test i32::range_ ... bench: 990 ns/iter (+/- 411)
test i32::while_ ... bench: 698 ns/iter (+/- 3)

test i64::range_ ... bench: 665 ns/iter (+/- 32)
test i64::while_ ... bench: 637 ns/iter (+/- 42)

test i8::range_ ... bench: 1353 ns/iter (+/- 56)
test i8::while_ ... bench: 1215 ns/iter (+/- 80)

test int::range_ ... bench: 620 ns/iter (+/- 43)
test int::while_ ... bench: 657 ns/iter (+/- 171)

test u16::range_ ... bench: 1345 ns/iter (+/- 89)
test u16::while_ ... bench: 651 ns/iter (+/- 39)

test u32::range_ ... bench: 930 ns/iter (+/- 29)
test u32::while_ ... bench: 656 ns/iter (+/- 51)

test u64::range_ ... bench: 620 ns/iter (+/- 42)
test u64::while_ ... bench: 622 ns/iter (+/- 10)

test u8::range_ ... bench: 1332 ns/iter (+/- 93)
test u8::while_ ... bench: 1215 ns/iter (+/- 21)

test uint::range_ ... bench: 618 ns/iter (+/- 9)
test uint::while_ ... bench: 622 ns/iter (+/- 44)
```

This was tested on Linux (x86-64), with the latest compiler code, and compiled with -O.

Benchmark code here (credit @huonw):
https://gist.github.com/huonw/27100788d1d6a837d4a7
